title: 109_hr1272
content: The "Encouraging Work Act of 2005" is the short title of this Act. It includes modifications to the Work Opportunity Credit and Welfare-to-Work Credit. The "Encouraging Work Act of 2005" makes the Work Opportunity Credit permanent, removes termination clauses, adjusts eligibility for ex-felons regardless of family income, increases the maximum age for food stamp recipients to 40, and raises the age limit for designated community residents. The code is amended to define a designated community resident as an individual aged 18-40 with their primary residence in a specified zone or community. The code is amended to clarify the treatment of individuals under individual work plans developed by employment networks. The Social Security Act amendments apply to individuals starting work for the employer after December 31, 2005. Consolidation of Work Opportunity Credit with Welfare-to-Work Credit. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new category of long-term family assistance recipients for tax purposes. This includes individuals certified by a designated local agency as part of a family receiving assistance under a IV-A program. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new category of long-term family assistance recipients for tax purposes, including individuals certified as part of a family receiving assistance under a IV-A program for at least 18 months. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new category of long-term family assistance recipients for tax purposes, including individuals certified as part of a family receiving assistance under a IV-A program for at least 18 months. This includes a provision for a credit for second-year wages for the employment of long-term family assistance recipients, where 50 percent of qualified second-year wages can be included in the work opportunity credit for the taxable year. The tax code allows for a credit for second-year wages for long-term family assistance recipients, capped at $10,000 per year. Qualified second-year wages are those paid to such recipients for services rendered in the year following the initial 1-year period. Special rules apply for agricultural and railway labor employees. The tax code is amended to increase the credit for second-year wages for long-term family assistance recipients to $10,000. The separate Welfare-to-Work Credit is repealed, and the effective date for these changes is for individuals starting work after December 31, 2005.
